3b7fec8e-eecc-4f1f-a28b-197e9396b36e.description: Earners of the Community Impact Professional (CIP) have demonstrated the competence new leaders need to recognize and apply the skills and behaviors required to help any business or organization impact its community from a human-centered, equitable lens. Earners are set up to successfully lead high-functioning teams and human-centered service projects while leading conversations around social issues affecting vulnerable populations and diversity, equity, inclusion, and belonging initiatives.
3b7fec8e-eecc-4f1f-a28b-197e9396b36e.name: Community Impact Professional (CIP)

alignments.name: Minimum Quality Standards and Indicators for Community Engagement
alignments.description: The CIP certification aligns to the "Minimum Quality Standards and Indicators for Community Engagement" Report (UNICEF), which sets forth core minimum standards developed in line with the principles of human rights‑ and community‑based approaches, such as participation, inclusion, and accountability.

alignments.name: Standard 1. Participation
alignments.description: A.1.3 Community members are given an opportunity to identify barriers to participation. A.1.4 Community members have positive experiences of participation. A.1.5 NGOs, CSOs, and partners identify and use strategies to sustain/increase participation. A.1.6 Community members identify the needs/priorities of various groups/sub‑groups in the community.

alignments.name: Standard 2. Empowerment & Ownership
alignments.description: A.2.2 Communities demonstrate an ability to explore key issues, develop action plans, carry out action plans and evaluate results. A.2.4 Community members feel that they ‘own’ the project; that it is ‘for them’. A.2.6 There is an increase in perceived and demonstrated community capacity by the end of the project.

alignments.name: Standard 3. Inclusion
alignments.description: A.3.2 Strategies have been developed and implemented to ensure as wide a range of inclusive representation as possible (e.g. gender, youth and children, minority groups, linguistic groups, vulnerable populations). A.3.4 Groups affected by the prioritized issue have been involved in leadership and mobilization activities.

alignments.name: Standard 4. Two-way Communication
alignments.description: A.4.1 Community leaders had direct access to government/CSO leaders in prioritizing community engagement goals. A.4.3 There has been an increase in knowledge about the issue among community members. A.4.6 CE platforms have facilitated two‑way communication and feedback for decision‑making and action by local stakeholders (including young people).

alignments.name: Standard 5. Adaptability and Localization
alignments.description: A.5.1 Communities are able to influence and guide project priorities and actions. A.5.2 Community support is assessed before initiating projects or activities. A.5.8 CE platforms/processes have been adapted to address specifics of local contexts, programmatic areas and special requirements of stakeholders (including young people).

alignments.name: Standard 7. Informed Design
alignments.description: B.7.2 Communities have influenced project plans.

alignments.name: Standard 8. Planning and Preparation
alignments.description: B.8.1 A participatory assessment has been conducted, and results shared with communities. B.8.2 Transparency and accountability have been established with communities through the development of a written community action plan co‑developed with community stakeholders.

alignments.name: Standard 9. Managing Activities
alignments.description: B.9.1 A community action plan has detailed community interests, defined the roles and responsibilities of programs, and community actors, timeframe for implementation, and progress benchmarks. B.9.5 Community mobilizers have access to regular training and responsive supervision. B.9.6 Project outcomes are consistent with community expectations...

alignments.name: Standard 10. Monitoring, Evaluation & Learning
alignments.description: B.10.1 Qualitative and quantitative indicators for community engagement have been co‑developed with local communities. B.10.2 Predefined indicators have been locally validated to ensure that they aligned with community priorities. B.10.5 Evaluations have been disseminated within organizations, to governments, to local communities and to partners.

alignments.name: Standard 12. Partner Coordination
alignments.description: C.12.2 Identification of CSO and community organization partners has been inclusive and represents the social, cultural, gender, age and religious distribution of the communities. C.12.5 Community members can clearly identify partners, and know how to address with questions, conflicts, or accountability issues.

alignments.name: Standard 13. Integration
alignments.description: C.13.1 All sections of the organization recognize that community engagement is a cross‑cutting activity with relevance for other sectors. C.13.4 Internal organizational processes are in place to resolve conflicts and competition between other sectors and community engagement capacities, to facilitate integration.

badge_template_activities.title: Applicants are encouraged to/nominated to apply by their supervisor/manager and should be age 18+ on the date applications are due.

Applicants should have a demonstrated interest in community issues and a record of leadership in voluntary community activities or possess a passion for youth, social justice, and community engagement. You must also occupy a position of leadership reflecting significant achievement relative to age and providing the opportunity to influence issues facing our community significantly.

All candidates are expected to fulfill the training requirements for the Lead Self, Lead Others, and Lead Community modules of the Rising Star Leadership Program. The training requirements are facilitated through blended learning formats (self-guided online training and in-person workshop facilitated during each monthly Mastermind Session).
Be able to commit to the attendance and time requirements.

Complete a personal leadership development plan and fulfill your community engagement project with ProAct. Complete your Youth Workshop Facilitator Training, complete the Community Impact Professional exam.

A minimum of 3 hours/month of community service with vulnerable youth, Manage at least one service project (usually occurs on a Saturday) using ProAct's Project Planning Formula, Facilitate 4 youth workshops for your sponsored school, Recruit at least five (5) Site Ambassadors,

66771803-9826-4074-8758-a23f5e3ebcd7.description: Impactful Workplaces recognize that employees are an organization's greatest resource and make a critical difference in an organization's ability to have a social impact in the community. Impactful workplaces have well-informed, well-intentioned employees who invest significantly in their local community with time, talent, and treasure.
66771803-9826-4074-8758-a23f5e3ebcd7.name: Impactful Workplace

badge_template_activities.title: Have at least 10% of your workforce earn a Community Impact Professional (CIP) Credential.
Have an annual community and/or volunteer engagement rhythm amongst at least 30% of your workforce.
Have at least 40% of your workforce complete DEIB training to understand better the vulnerable communities we serve.

d97ce10c-1cae-49bf-be4d-a44cbbe6ff47.description: Organizations and Companies that earn the Inclusive Organization badge have created a workplace based on equity and belonging. It has increased effectiveness, sense of purpose, hope, courage, innovation, communication, humility, vulnerability, patience, productivity, conviction, intentionality, and support for their employees; and they have invested in continual, active learning and education of Diversity, Equity, Inclusion, and Belonging.
d97ce10c-1cae-49bf-be4d-a44cbbe6ff47.name: Inclusive Organization

alignments.name: Minimum Quality Standards and Indicators for Community Engagement
alignments.description: The Inclusive Organization credential aligns to the "Minimum Quality Standards and Indicators for Community Engagement" Report (UNICEF), which sets forth core minimum standards developed in line with the principles of human rights‑ and community‑based approaches, such as participation, inclusion, and accountability.

alignments.name: Standard 1. Participation
alignments.description: A.1.3 Community members are given an opportunity to identify barriers to participation. A.1.4 Community members have positive experiences of participation. alignments.description: A.2.2 Communities demonstrate an ability to explore key issues, develop action plans, carry out action plans and evaluate results. A.2.4 Community members feel that they ‘own’ the project; that it is ‘for them’. A.2.6 There is an increase in perceived and demonstrated community capacity by the end of the project.

alignments.name: Standard 3. Inclusion
alignments.description: A.3.2 Strategies have been developed and implemented to ensure as wide a range of inclusive representation as possible (e.g. gender, youth and children, minority groups, linguistic groups, vulnerable populations). A.3.4 Groups affected by the prioritized issue have been involved in leadership and mobilization activities.

badge_template_activities.title: Have an annual rhythm of DEIB and leadership development in your organization.
Earn a 70% rating on a company-wide DEIB assessment/audit OR have at least 30% of your workforce earn a Community Impact Professional (CIP) Credential.

433336eb-9ceb-419a-a310-61b72e979deb.description: Earners of the Community Impact Youth Leader (CIYL) have demonstrated the competence young leaders need to recognize and apply the skills and behaviors required to help any organization impact its community from a human-centered, equitable lens. Earners are set up to be on a path to a leadership role within a business or nonprofit, and are equipped to champion conversations around social issues affecting vulnerable populations and diversity, equity, inclusion, and belonging initiatives.
433336eb-9ceb-419a-a310-61b72e979deb.name: Community Impact Youth Leader (CIYL)

badge_template_activities.title: Applicants are encouraged to/nominated to apply by a caring adult (e.g. educator, supervisor/manager, etc), and they should be age 15-18 on the date applications are due.

Applicants should have a demonstrated interest in community issues and a record of leadership in voluntary community activities or possess a passion for youth, social justice, and community engagement. You must also demonstrate commendable achievement relative to age.

All candidates are expected to fulfill the training requirements for the Lead Self, Lead Others, and Lead Community modules of the Rising Star Leadership Program. The training requirements are facilitated through blended learning formats (self-guided online training and in-person workshop facilitated during each monthly Mastermind Session).
Be able to commit to the attendance and time requirements.

Complete a personal leadership development plan and fulfill your community engagement project with ProAct. Complete your Youth Workshop Facilitator Training, complete the Community Impact Professional exam.

A minimum of one hour/month of community service with vulnerable youth, Manage at least one service project (usually occurs on a Saturday) using ProAct's Project Planning Formula, Facilitate at least 2 youth workshops for your sponsored school, Recruit at least two (2) Site Ambassadors.
